Text Mining Orkut’s Community Data with Python

Cultural Memory, Platform Neglect, and Digital Amnesia

Rodrigo Silva Ferreira

2025-12-09

About Me

Quick intro: chemistry → software → sociotechnical research.
Frame why Orkut matters personally and culturally.

Have you heard of Orkut?

Follow along…

www.github.com/rodrigosf672/orkut-pydataglobal2025

Gauge audience familiarity.
Mention that Orkut shaped Brazilian online culture long before Facebook.

Introduction

  • Orkut shaped early Brazilian internet culture.
  • Community names were a public form of self-curation.
  • After 2014, almost all platform data disappeared.
  • Only partial HTML snapshots survive.

Set up the problem: cultural loss + fragmented archives + why reconstruction is valuable.

Orkut Profile Example

Show the aesthetic and UX.
Point out public-facing identity signals through communities.

A More Recent Profile Example

Thank my friend for getting that screenshot!

Why Orkut Matters

  • Communities worked as a vocabulary of identity.
  • No algorithmic feeds: users curated themselves.
  • Names acted as expressive micro-texts.

Explain how community titles functioned like early status updates, humor, belonging cues.

Geographic Shifts (2004 → 2014)

Country 2004 2014
Brazil 5.16% 55.5%
US 51.36% 3.3%
India — 18.4%
China — 6.4%
Japan 7.74% 2.7%

Narrate the shift from US → Brazil → Brazil+India.
Important cultural context for interpreting the dataset.

Note

Orkut shifted from US-centric → Brazil + India + Global South

Reinforce the shift and why it matters for multilingual modeling.

Platform Timeline

    2004
    ───────────────────────────
    Launch


    2005
    ───────────────────────────
    Massive Brazilian adoption


    2007
    ───────────────────────────
    India becomes major hub


    2010
    ───────────────────────────
    Infrastructure migration


    2012
    ───────────────────────────
    Feature decay


    2014
    ───────────────────────────
    Shutdown

Show trajectory and platform decline.
Place the dataset historically.

Enshittification Cycle (Cory Doctorow)

    ┌────────────────────┐
    │ 1. User Benefit    │
    │--------------------│
    │ Generous features  │
    │ Little friction    │
    │ Goal: attract users│
    └─────────▲──────────┘
              │
              │ platform gains users
              ▼
    ┌────────────────────┐
    │ 2. Business Benefit│
    │--------------------│
    │ More ads, partners │
    │ Data extraction    │
    │ Goal: monetize     │
    └─────────▲──────────┘
              │
              │ platform extracts value
              ▼
    ┌────────────────────┐
    │ 3. Platform Benefit│
    │--------------------│
    │ Hostile UX         │
    │ Feature decay      │
    │ Goal: maximize rent│
    └─────────▲──────────┘
              │
              │ ecosystem collapses
              ▼
      (users + creators leave)

Situate Orkut’s decline within Doctorow’s broader analysis of platform incentives.
Emphasize that this pattern is structural: growth → extraction → collapse.
Use this as a bridge to why so much cultural material vanished and why reconstruction matters.

Platform Decline

  • 51M+ communities lost.
  • Almost all cultural material erased.
  • Remaining content = inconsistent web snapshots.

Emphasize digital amnesia and importance of recovery.

Orkut Archive in the Wayback Machine

Highlight how inconsistent and incomplete the archive is.
Motivates reconstruction work.

What Survives

  • 124,988 recoverable community names.
  • Variation across language, style, humor, identity cues.
  • Each title = a micro-text of early social networking.

Important

Clusters represent linguistic similarity; not user groups.

Clarify what the dataset actually is and isn’t.
Prevent misinterpretation: this is linguistic, not social network analysis.

Reconstruction Challenges

  • No API
  • Broken/partial HTML
  • Layout varies by year
  • Missing pagination
  • Duplicate and inconsistent content

Summarize scraping complexity; justify defensive parsing choices.

Reconstruction Approach

  • Multiple CSS fallbacks
  • Defensive parsing
  • Deduplication
  • Noise filtering
  • Stored as CSV for reproducibility

Reassure reproducibility.
Highlight careful engineering despite messy source data.

Linguistic Foundations

  • Community names encode stance, identity, humor, belonging.
  • They form a unique record of early internet culture.
  • Analysis combines stylometry and semantics.

Explain why stylometry + semantics complement each other.

Stylometric Features

  • Character length:
    “eu te amo” → “eu te amooooo”

  • Caps ratio: “EU TE AMO” vs. “Eu te amo”

  • Vowel elongation:
    “nooossa”

  • Punctuation elongation: “vem!!!” / “oi????”

  • Symbol density: “♥ eu te amo ♥”

  • Miguxês (k_style): “aki, keru, naum”

Keep examples intuitive.
Emphasize expressive registers and internet-era writing styles.

Semantic Features

  • Multilingual embeddings (SentenceTransformers)
  • UMAP projection
  • KMeans / HDBSCAN / BERTopic clustering

Explain pipeline: embeddings capture meaning, UMAP shows structure, clustering identifies thematic groups.

Semantic Features

  • Multilingual embeddings (SentenceTransformers)
  • UMAP projection
  • KMeans / HDBSCAN / BERTopic clustering

Explain pipeline: embeddings capture meaning, UMAP shows structure, clustering identifies thematic groups.

Preview of Analyses

In the interactive Quarto report, I’ll walk through:

  • Language distribution
  • Semantic space (UMAP)
  • Stylometry (caps-lock, Miguxês)
  • Topic modeling with BERTopic
  • Sentiment structure

These plots reveal structure, style, and expressive patterns across community names.

Set expectations: slides show static previews; real exploration happens in the QMD report.

Language Distribution

static preview — interactive version shown in the Quarto report

Mention mix of Portuguese, English, Spanish, and smaller languages.

Semantic Map (UMAP)

static preview — interactive exploration in the Quarto report

Axes aren’t interpretable; emphasis is local neighborhoods.

Caps Lock Stylometry

static preview — deeper inspection in the Quarto report

Use caps ratio as a proxy for emotional intensity or stylistic emphasis.

Miguxês Stylometry

static preview — full analysis in the Quarto report

Explain Miguxês as a youth-coded register.

BERTopic: Micro-topic Barcharts

static preview — interactive version in the Quarto report

Highlight intuitive topics: affection, fandom, jokes, identity.

BERTopic: Intertopic Distance Map

static preview — interactive exploration in the Quarto report

Interpret topic families and proximity.

Sentiment Mapping

static preview — interactive version in the Quarto report

Explain VADER limitations for Portuguese.

Sentiment Interpretation

  • Portuguese positive expressions are formulaic → cluster tightly
  • Negative expressions vary syntactically → disperse
  • VADER used cautiously (English model)

Acknowledge limitations but highlight patterns.

Recap of Analytical Findings

  • Languages reflect Orkut’s cultural geography
  • Semantic space shows clusters of humor, affect, fandom, locality
  • Stylometry captures expressive registers
  • BERTopic reveals micro-topics
  • Sentiment patterns shaped by formulaic vs. varied expressions

Full interactive walkthrough is available in the Quarto report (orkut_analysis.qmd).

High-level summary before moving to implications.

Conclusion

  • Orkut preserves a unique moment in online identity-making.
  • Communities were a lightweight identity system.
  • Expressive registers include humor, affect, locality, fandom, youth styles.
  • Computational methods reconstruct lost cultural landscapes.

End with cultural significance + methodological contribution.

Why This Matters

  • Platforms vanish; cultural memory disappears.
  • Surviving fragments still hold sociological value.
  • Orkut shows intentional, user-driven identity: no algorithmic mediation.

Connect to broader debates on digital memory and platform governance.

Future Directions

  • Richer sociolinguistic modeling
  • Geographic identity signals
  • Register mapping across semantic space
  • Archival forum thread analysis
  • Multi-feature alignment (semantics × style × sentiment)

Encourage collaboration; mention potential for community-based archival projects.
